1.09.text:
Child: THERE ONCE WAS A TIME WHEN WE WERE
TRULY FREE -- FREE OF WORRY, FREE OF FEAR,

35.16.text:

IN ASSOCIATION WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER

38.16.text:
THIS IS "SECOND OPINION,"AND I'M YOUR HOST,
DR.

41.28.text:
THIS WEEK, "MYTH OR MEDICINE," DOES A NORMAL
BRAIN SCAN RULE OUT A CONCUSSION?

47.30.text:
EVERY CONCUSSION HAS THE POTENTIAL FOR THIS
LIFE-THREATENING BLEEDING IN THE BRAIN.

51.95.text:
AND SPECIAL GUEST MONICA COOK, WHOSE TIME
ON THE SOCCER FIELD HAS BROUGHT HER HERE FOR

58.24.text:
LAST SEASON I GOT HIT TWICE, TWO CONSECUTIVE
GAMES, SO TWO DAYS IN A ROW.

67.31.text: WELL, THANKS SO MUCH FOR BEING HERE, MONICA.

70.87.text:
WE'VE GOT A LOT OF DETAILS FOR
YOU TO FILL IN FOR US, AND I WANT TO GET TO

74.22.text:
THEM, AND I WANT TO INTRODUCE YOU TO YOUR
"SECOND OPINION" PANEL.

76.91.text:
THESE ARE PEOPLE WHO ARE HERE TO HELP YOU,
AND YOU'RE GOING TO BE ABLE TO GET YOUR SECOND

80.01.text:
OPINION FROM THEM BY THE TIME THIS BROADCAST
IS OVER.

83.18.text:
WE HAVE PRIMARY CARE DOCTOR FROM THE UNIVERSITY
OF ROCHESTER, DR.

85.99.text: LISA HARRIS, AND WE HAVE DR.

88.56.text:
JULIAN BAILES FROM THE NORTH SHORE UNIVERSITY
HEALTH SYSTEM -- DR.

93.01.text:
NOW, MONICA, WE TALKED EARLIER,
AND I KNOW YOU'VE GOT A LOT OF DETAILS OF

95.97.text:
YOUR STORY, SO WHY DON'T YOU BRING US UP TO
SPEED AS TO BASICALLY WHY YOU'RE HERE?

101.23.text: WHEN DID YOU START HAVING PROBLEMS?

103.32.text:
LET'S EVEN GO BACK FURTHER -- WHEN DID YOU
START PLAYING SOCCER?

106.70.text:
I STARTED PLAYING SOCCER WHEN I WAS TEN YEARS
OLD, AND I PLAYED ALL THROUGH MIDDLE SCHOOL,

111.95.text:
ALL THROUGH HIGH SCHOOL, AND I GOT MY FIRST
CONCUSSION MY FRESHMAN YEAR OF COLLEGE.

116.40.text:
ALL RIGHT, WELL, EVEN BEFORE YOU KNEW THAT
YOU HAD A CONCUSSION, I WANT A LITTLE MORE

120.06.text:
DETAIL ON THIS, BECAUSE THAT'S TOO EASY, "I
GOT A CONCUSSION."

123.20.text:
YOU WERE PLAYING SOCCER, AND, BECAUSE, I MEAN,
SOCCER'S NOT A CONTACT SPORT, RIGHT?

130.38.text: OR MAYBE IT IS, THE WAY YOU GUYS PLAY IT.

136.38.text:
I HEADED A BALL OFF A PUNT, AND I HEADED IT
IMPROPERLY, SO I KIND OF CAUGHT IT ON THE

139.62.text: YOU'LL FORGIVE ME, OFF A PUNT?

141.62.text: A PUNT, SO A GOALIE PUNTS --

143.62.text:
SO THE GOALIE KICKED THE BALL AND YOU PUT
YOUR HEAD IN THE WAY.

145.62.text:
[ LAUGHS ] YEAH, IT WENT REALLY HIGH IN THE
AIR AND CAME BACK DOWN AND I KIND OF CAUGHT

147.92.text:
IT OFF THE TOP OR THE BACK OF MY HEAD, WHICH
IS NOT WHERE YOU'RE SUPPOSED TO HEAD THE BALL,

151.55.text:
BUT I FELT MY HEAD KIND OF GO BACK A LITTLE
BIT. AND I DIDN'T FALL OVEROR GET KNOCKED

158.64.text: I DIDN'T EVEN COME OUT OF THE GAME OR ANYTHING.

159.87.text:
IT FELT A LITTLE FUNNY WHEN I TOOK THE HIT,
BUT I FINISHED THE GAME, AND THEN THAT NIGHT

165.46.text:
I HAD A LITTLE BIT OF A HEADACHE, BUT NOT
TOO BAD. AND WHEN I WOKE UP THE NEXT MORNING,

171.40.text:
WHEN YOU SAY REALLY, REALLY SICK, WHAT DO
YOU MEAN?

173.68.text:
I HAD A HEADACHE, MY STOMACH WAS JUST KIND
OF UNEASY, I WAS KIND OF NAUSEOUS -- I WASN'T

177.98.text:
SICK TO MY STOMACH, BUT I JUST DIDN'T FEEL
GOOD.

180.97.text:
I WAS REALLY UPSET ABOUT, I'M NOT EVEN SURE
WHAT, AND I JUST THOUGHT MAYBE I HAD A LITTLE

188.39.text:
BIT, LIKE A TOUCH OF THE FLU OR STOMACH BUG
OR SOMETHING LIKE THAT.

192.09.text: NOW, SHE MENTIONED THE WORD CONCUSSION.

193.44.text:
DOES THAT SOUND LIKE SOMETHING THAT, IF YOU
WERE HER PRIMARY CARE DOC, YOU WOULD HAVE

198.55.text:
LISA HARRIS:
ABSOLUTELY -- I MEAN, SHE HAS SOME VERY CLASSIC

199.73.text:
SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS OF A HEAD INJURY OR WHAT
WE COMMONLY CALL CONCUSSION.

204.43.text:
SO SHE HAD A TRAUMA TO THE HEAD OR A BACK-AND-FORTH
MOTION TO THE HEAD OR A STRIKING TO THE HEAD

211.70.text:
AND FOLLOWED WITH HEADACHE, WITH CONFUSION,
WITH NAUSEA, WITH MOOD SWINGS OR IRRITABILITY

219.13.text:
-- ALL OF THOSE ARE FEATURES OF A HEAD INJURY
OR SOME DAMAGE TO THE BRAIN.

223.81.text:
SO AFTER THAT, YOU'RE AT HOME, YOU'RE NOT
FEELING WELL -- MAYBE SOME NAUSEA, HEADACHE,

228.99.text: NOT FEELING YOURSELF OR A LITTLE OUT OF IT?

231.57.text:
DID YOU GO BACK AND PLAY AGAIN, OR DID YOU
SIT OUT?

235.76.text:
UM, I SKIPPED PRACTICE THE NEXT DAY BECAUSE
I THOUGHT I WAS SICK, AND THEN WHEN IT STILL

239.44.text:
DIDN'T IMPROVE, I WENT AND SAW THE TRAINER,
AND I TOOK SOME TESTS, AND HE KIND OF DETERMINED

245.64.text:
THAT I HAD A CONCUSSION AND I SHOULD SIT,
SO I SAT OUT FOR A WHILE AFTER THAT.

252.09.text: WHAT DOES ANYBODY DO TO TEST FOR A CONCUSSION?

254.70.text:
I'VE SEEN FOOTBALL MOVIES WHERE THEY SAY,
"HOW MANY FINGERS AM I SHOWING," AND IF YOU

257.87.text: SAY TWO, THEY PUT YOU BACK IN THE GAME.

262.35.text:
THE TEST BASICALLY IS TO INTERVIEW THE PERSON
OR ATHLETE AND THEN TO DO A NEUROLOGICAL EXAMINATION,

267.29.text:
BUT TYPICALLY THOSE ARE NORMAL, AND THAT'S
PART OF THE PROBLEM WITH CONCUSSION IS THAT

271.22.text:
THE PATIENT IS WALKING AND TALKING, AND THEY
HAVE A "NORMAL" EXAM.

275.04.text: SO YOU HAVE TO GO BEYOND THAT.

276.91.text:
THE NUMBER-ONE THING WE GO BY IS THE SYMPTOM
CHECKLIST.

281.71.text:
SOUNDS LIKE MONICA HAD SEVERAL THAT WOULD
BE CONCERNING.

284.85.text:
AND THEN SOMETIMES WE GO TO A NEUROPSYCHOLOGICAL
TEST --

291.78.text:
WELL, THAT'S NOW DONE ORDINARILY COMPUTERIZED,
AND THAT'S REALLY LOOKING AT THINGS LIKE VERBAL

295.04.text:
MEMORY AND VISUAL PROCESSING, THINGS LIKE
THAT, THAT REALLY DRILL DOWN HOW THE BRAIN

302.49.text:
SO IT'S FAR MORE SUBTLE THAN THE EARLIER TESTS
WE USED TO DO.

308.46.text: WELL, YOU KEPT TRYING TO PLAY, MONICA?

309.46.text: DID YOU GET BACK IN THE GAME FINALLY?

310.46.text:
MONICA
YEAH, I SAW A DOCTOR IN THE TRAINING ROOM,

313.41.text:
AND I WAS HAVING HEADACHES LIKE EVERY NIGHT,
BUT I WAS MUCH BETTER THAN THE FIRST DAY I

317.39.text:
CAME BACK, AND SO HE ASKED ME IF I WANTED
TO PLAY, AND I SAID OF COURSE I WANTED TO

322.27.text: SO I PUT ON SORT OF A PADDED HEAD GEAR --

325.67.text:
PETER SALGO:
I WANT TO STOP YOU -- WHAT YEAR OF COLLEGE

332.03.text: THAT PUTS YOU WHAT 17, 18 YEARS OLD?

335.03.text: AND THE DOC SAYS, "DO YOU WANT TO PLAY?"

336.03.text:
DOES HE, DO YOU THINK ANY DOC IS EVER GOING
TO GET, "NO, DOC, PLEASE SIT ME DOWN?"

344.95.text:
ATHLETES, THEY'RE GOING TO LIE AND DO WHATEVER
THEY NEED TO DO TO GET BACK IN THE GAME.

346.95.text:
I WANT TO KEEP GOING, BUT I JUST WANT TO ASK
A QUESTION -- YOU CAN BE AS CRITICAL AS YOU

349.66.text:
THE BEHAVIOR OF THAT DOC TO ASK THAT QUESTION,
WAS IT APPROPRIATE OR NOT?

354.04.text:
WELL, IT'S NOT INAPPROPRIATE IF THAT WAS ONE
OF MANY QUESTIONS.

356.79.text:
YOU REALLY HAVE TO GET AT HOW THE PATIENT
IS DOING, WHAT THE SYMPTOMS ARE, AND TRY TO

361.75.text: SEE IF YOU CAN DECIDE WHAT'S GOING ON.

363.26.text:
THIS IS AN INJURY THAT HAS NO, ORDINARILY,
NO OUTWARD MANIFESTATIONS.

369.03.text:
RIGHT, AND I THINK THE ISSUE IS NOT SO MUCH
THE QUESTION BUT WHETHER OR NOT HE BASED HIS

374.86.text: IN ANY EVENT, YOU WENT BACK AND PLAYED?

380.86.text:
I TRIED TO PLAY IN A FEW PRACTICES, I GOT
IN ONE MORE GAME, AND AGAIN I GOT THROUGH

383.04.text:
THE ENTIRE GAME, AS I NORMALLY WOULD, BUT
IT WAS AFTERWARDS THAT I REALLY DIDN'T FEEL

387.94.text: SO AFTER THAT, I SAT AGAIN.

389.94.text:
DID THEY SEND YOU TO A DOCTOR AT THAT POINT,
OR WHAT HAPPENED?

393.26.text:
YEAH, SO I SAT, AND I WAITED A WHILE TO SEE
IF THE SYMPTOMS WOULD CLEAR UP, AND EVENTUALLY

397.25.text: I WENT TO SEE A NEUROLOGIST.

399.25.text: AND WHAT DID THE NEUROLOGIST SAY?

401.25.text: HE DIAGNOSED ME WITH POST-CONCUSSION SYNDROME.

407.91.text:
IT'S HAVING SYMPTOMS OF A CONCUSSION AFTER
A CONCUSSION.

410.68.text: I WAS AFRAID YOU WERE GOING TO SAY THAT!

413.85.text:
SO IT'S ASSUMING THAT THE ACUTE INJURY HAS
"RESOLVED" AND PATIENTS HAVE ONGOING SYMPTOMS,

420.16.text: I WANT TO BACKTRACK A LITTLE BIT.

421.48.text:
WHEN MONICA GOT HIT THE FIRST TIME AND SHE
FELT FUNNY AND HER HEAD WAS EXTENDED -- RIGHT,

426.05.text:
IT WENT BACK, SHOULD SHE HAVE BEEN PULLED
FROM THE GAME RIGHT THEN?

434.29.text: BOTH OF YOU AGREE ON THAT OR NO?

442.29.text: YOU DO. AND HOW DO YOU KNOW THAT?

447.29.text:
SO SHE HAD SYMPTOMS INITIALLY, AND THAT'S
ONE OF THE THINGS YOU HAVE TO LOOK FOR, AND

448.29.text:
THAT'S ONE OF THE THINGS THAT WE LOOK FOR
NOW.

449.29.text:
SO IF SHE WAS LOOKING DAZED, ACTING A LITTLE
CONFUSED, COMPLAINING OF HEADACHE OR NAUSEA

450.42.text:
OR ANY OTHER SYMPTOM, YOU GET PULLED FROM
THE GAME.

453.77.text: ALL RIGHT, SO WHAT ARE YOU GOING TO DO?

455.77.text:
I MEAN, GIVE HER MEDICINE ON THE SIDELINES,
ANYTHING?

458.77.text:
THE BIG THING IS, IF YOU HAVE A CONCERN, AS
A BYSTANDER, OBSERVER, OR AN ATHLETIC TRAINER,

463.39.text:
YOU NEED TO PULL THEM OUT AND EVALUATE THEM,
AND THEN YOU MAKE A DIAGNOSIS OR A SUSPECTED

469.36.text:
AND IF THE ANSWER IS YES, THEY DON'T GO BACK
TO PLAY IN THAT DAY, THAT PRACTICE, OR THAT

477.52.text:
THERE IS NO MEDICATION AT THAT STAGE, AND
USUALLY MOST OF THEM RESOLVE.

482.49.text:
BUT, YOU KNOW, I JUST REALIZED SOMETHING -- YOU
MENTIONED THE WORD CONCUSSION, WE'VE TALKED

485.49.text:
ABOUT THE WORD CONCUSSION, WE'VE EVEN GONE
BEYOND IT TO POST-CONCUSSION SYNDROME.

496.23.text:
IT COULD BE DEFINED ANY NUMBER OF WAYS, BUT
PRIMARILY IT'S BRAIN NOT WORKING RIGHT AFTER

500.84.text:
A MECHANICAL HIT OR TEMPORARY NEUROLOGICAL
DYSFUNCTION IS ANOTHER WAY DOCTORS TALK ABOUT

506.67.text:
IT, BUT IT'S A BRAIN DISTURBANCE THAT IS ORDINARILY
TEMPORARY, AND THEN IT WILL RESOLVE, PROBABLY

515.42.text:
BUT I NOTICE WHAT YOU SAID DID NOT INVOLVE
PHYSIOLOGY, DID NOT INVOLVE SPECIFIC ANATOMY,

522.61.text:
IT IS, "THE BRAIN IS NOT WORKING RIGHT AFTER
YOU HIT IT." IS THAT GOOD ENOUGH?

528.83.text:
WELL, YES AND NO -- I THINK ONE OF THE THINGS
WE'VE COME TO REALIZE ABOUT CONCUSSION -- I

531.69.text:
THINK IN THE PAST WE'VE THOUGHT THAT IT'S
A DIRECT BLOW TO THE BRAIN, ALMOST LIKE A

536.81.text: BRUISE OR A PUNCH TO AN ARM OR EXTREMITY.

539.50.text:
AND WHAT WE REALIZE NOW IS THAT IT'S MUCH
MORE COMPLICATED THAN THAT --

543.29.text: I WAS AFRAID YOU WERE GOING TO SAY THAT.

547.29.text:
IT HAS TO DO WITH THE HORMONES AND THE CHEMICALS
THAT THE BRAIN PRODUCES AND HOW IT FUNCTIONS

550.15.text:
OVERALL, AND THAT'S WHY WE GET INTO COGNITIVE
EVALUATIONS, AND THAT'S WHY SOMETIMES IT'S

554.32.text:
DIFFICULT TO PINPOINT, BECAUSE YOU CAN'T LOOK
AT SOMEBODY AND SAY, "OH, YOUR BRAIN IS NOT

563.12.text:
DID ANYBODY SAY, "DON'T GO TO SLEEP BECAUSE
WE'RE AFRAID YOU DON'T WAKE UP?

566.01.text: WE WERE PAST THAT PART, RIGHT?

567.95.text: BUT THEY PUT YOU ON DRUGS FOR YOUR HEADACHE?

570.79.text:
YES, SO AFTER I SAW THE FIRST NEUROLOGIST,
HE GAVE ME KIND OF A DAILY HEADACHE PAINKILLER

576.20.text:
PREVENTATIVE TYPE OF MEDICINE, SO I TOOK THAT
EVERY DAY.

579.97.text:
I MEAN, I WAS IN MY FIRST QUARTER OF COLLEGE,
SO I WAS COMING UP ON FINALS AND STUFF, SO

584.27.text:
I STARTED TAKING THAT AND BASICALLY JUST RESTED,
SO STOPPED AN FORM OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY.

591.02.text: AND DID YOU SIT OUT THE REST OF THE SEASON?

595.02.text:
WHEN YOU CAME BACK, I KNOW WE HAVE HAD A DISCUSSION
ABOUT THIS -- YOU TRIED WEARING SOME HEAD

599.37.text:
Cook: UM, I DON'T KNOW IF IT HELPED -- I MEAN,
IT MADE ME A LITTLE BIT MORE AWARE OF MY HEAD

603.44.text:
AND WHAT I WAS DOING WITH IT AS FAR AS GOING
IN FOR HEAD BALLS AND GOING IN FOR TACKLES

608.77.text:
BUT YOU'RE NOT SURE -- DOES WEARING HEAD PROTECTION
PROTECT YOU AGAINST CONCUSSIONS?

616.29.text: YOU'VE WORKED WITH THE NFL TOO, RIGHT?

619.83.text: NOT IN SOCCER, LET ME PUT IT --

622.83.text:
WELL, FIRST OF ALL, LISA'S RIGHT, IN SOCCER
THERE'S NO HEAD GEAR FOR THE MOST PART.

624.73.text: THERE IS NO CONCUSSION-PROOF HELMET IN FOOTBALL.

628.32.text:
THERE IS A PHENOMENON WHERE THE BRAIN MOVES
AROUND INSIDE THE SKULL -- WE CALL THAT "SLOSH,"

637.82.text:
WELL, IT'S A TERM THAT I THINK MOST PEOPLE
GET. AND THE BRAIN IS FREELY ABLE TO MOVE,

639.02.text:
SO THAT'S GOING TO HAPPEN NO MATTER WHAT YOU'RE
WEARING.

642.57.text:
NOW, HELMETS DO A GREAT JOB OF PREVENTING
MAJOR BRAIN INJURY AND SKULL FRACTURES, THINGS

647.88.text:
LIKE THAT, AND THEY PREVENT A LOT OF CONCUSSIONS,
BUT THEY HAVEN'T BEEN TOTALLY ABLE TO ELIMINATE

654.07.text:
THE ISSUE OF CONCUSSION -- THAT'S ONE REASON
WE STILL TALK ABOUT IT IN FOOTBALL.

658.17.text:
WELL, DESPITE THAT, DESPITE THE FACT THAT
YOU SAT OUT FOR A WHILE, YOU PLAYED TWO MORE

661.21.text:
YEARS, AND YOU GOT TWO MORE HITS, AT LEAST,
RIGHT, TO THE HEAD?

664.72.text:
YEAH, I PLAYED TWO YEARS PROBABLY WITHOUT
ANY SIGNIFICANT EVENTS, AND THEN DURING MY

668.81.text:
LAST SEASON, I GOT HIT TWICE, TWO CONSECUTIVE
GAMES.

672.63.text: SO TWO DAYS IN A ROW, PRETTY SIGNIFICANT --

676.03.text: WHAT DID THAT DO TO YOUR HEADACHES?

678.03.text:
THEY JUST INCREASED THE FREQUENCY AND THE
SEVERITY.

679.82.text:
SO I HAD HEADACHES EVERY ONCE IN A WHILE,
EVERY MONTH OR SO PRETTY BAD THROUGHOUT -- I

684.29.text:
JUST
STARTED -- BASICALLY DEVELOPED FREQUENT HEADACHES

688.55.text:
SO SHE'S GETTING MORE HEADACHES, SHE'S BEEN
HIT A COUPLE MORE TIMES.

691.32.text:
I KNOW THE WORD YOU MENTIONED TO ME WHEN WE
WERE TALKING IS YOU THOUGHT YOU MIGHT HAVE

703.92.text:
WELL, IT IS TYPICAL THAT IF YOU CONTINUE TO
GET HIT, ESPECIALLY IF YOU HAVE A SECOND HIT

704.92.text:
AS SHE DESCRIBED TWO YEARS LATER, AFTER THE
FIRST HIT, THAT TYPICALLY CAN ACCELERATE THINGS

711.84.text:
AND CREATE A CHRONIC STATE WHERE THE BRAIN
HASN'T HEALED AND THE SYMPTOMS CONTINUE.

720.95.text: OR SHOULD SHE HAVE HUNG THEM UP?

725.76.text: I THINK SHE PROBABLY SHOULD HAVE BEEN PULLED.

731.63.text: WELL, AGAIN, HARD TO GIVE A SHORT ANSWER.

732.63.text: THERE ARE WAYS TO MANAGE AROUND THAT.

733.63.text:
IT SOUNDS LIKE SHE SHOULDN'T HAVE PLAYED ANYMORE
AFTER THE SECOND HIT, I THINK, WHEN SHE WAS

740.42.text:
THERE ARE WAYS TO MANAGE THIS, BUT IN GENERAL,
NO, IF THE PLAYER IS SYMPTOMATIC, THEY SHOULDN'T

747.71.text:
ENOUGH, ENOUGH, AS WHAT MY MOTHER WOULD SAY,
ENOUGH!

751.25.text: AND YOU GOT POPPED AGAIN, DIDN'T YOU?

759.08.text:
I KIND OF GOT -- I FELL INTO THE BOARD, SO
I DIDN'T ACTUALLY HIT MY HEAD, BUT I GOT MORE

761.50.text: OF LIKE A WHIPLASH TO MY NECK.

764.27.text: OKAY AND YOU WENT TO THE EMERGENCY ROOM?

769.27.text: DID THEY DO ANY DIAGNOSTIC STUDIES?

771.27.text: THEY DID A CAT SCAN, YEAH.

773.27.text:
SO THEY GOT A CAT SCAN OF YOUR HEAD, AND IT
SHOWED...?

777.27.text:
ALL RIGHT, SHE'S GOT A NEGATIVE CAT SCAN,
SHE'S NORMAL.

783.27.text:
BUT I THOUGHT IT'S A BRAIN INJURY -- WHY DIDN'T
I SEE THIS ON THE CAT SCAN?

786.27.text: YOU'RE NOT GOING TO SEE IT ON A CAT SCAN.

788.27.text:
SO HOW CAN THERE BE INJURY IF I DON'T SEE
IT ON THE X-RAY?

791.27.text:
WELL, IT'S NOT SOMETHING THAT SHOWS ON CAT
SCANS.

793.27.text: YOU DON'T HAVE SWELLING OF THE BRAIN.

794.27.text:
SO BY DEFINITION, CONCUSSION IS SUPPOSED TO
HAVE A NEGATIVE CAT SCAN OR A NORMAL CAT SCAN.

800.07.text:
SO THAT'S AGAIN WHY YOU HAVE TO GO TO OTHER
FORMS OF TESTING.

805.41.text:
BECAUSE A PARENT WILL TAKE A KID TO THE EMERGENCY
ROOM, HEAR THAT THE CAT SCAN IS NEGATIVE,

809.70.text:
NORMAL, AND SAY, "GREAT, MY KID CAN GO BACK
AND PLAY."

814.36.text:
AND THAT'S WHY IT'S SO IMPORTANT FOR CHILDREN
IN PARTICULAR, TO ASK THE PARENTS, "HOW IS

817.72.text: HAS THEIR BEHAVIOR CHANGED AT ALL?

823.69.text:
ALL RIGHT, SO YOU EVENTUALLY DECIDED TO QUIT
RIGHT ABOUT THAT TIME, RIGHT?

828.72.text:
YOU WANTED GOOD GRADES, YOU DIDN'T WANT YOUR
BRAIN TO GET MESSED UP.

834.72.text:
NOW I'M IN GRADUATE SCHOOL, AND I'M A COACH
NOW.

841.72.text: I WANT TO STOP YOU RIGHT THERE.

842.72.text:
I KNOW THAT YOU HAD A TURNING POINT IN YOUR
LIFE AND YOU ARE HERE TO LOOK FOR A SECOND

843.72.text:
OPINION, AND WE'RE GOING TO GET THAT FOR YOU,
AND I WANT THE PANEL TO STAY RIGHT WHERE YOU

846.84.text:
ARE TOO BECAUSE WE'LL BE RIGHT BACK TO HEAR
THIS SECOND OPINION, BUT FIRST HERE'S THIS

854.11.text: AN ATHLETE SUFFERS A BLOW TO THE HEAD.

857.81.text:
AFTER GOING TO THE HOSPITAL, HE GETS A CAT
SCAN THAT COMES BACK NORMAL.

862.88.text:
A NORMAL BRAIN SCAN RULES OUT A CONCUSSION,
RIGHT?

869.51.text:
"A NORMAL CT SCAN OR A NORMAL MRI RULES OUT
A CONCUSSION."

874.14.text: THAT'S A MYTH, AND I'M GOING TO TELL YOU WHY.

879.28.text:
I'M ASSOCIATE PROFESSOR OF EMERGENCY MEDICINE
AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER SCHOOL OF MEDICINE

885.41.text:
CURRENTLY THE WAY A CONCUSSION IS DEFINED
IS A BLOW TO THE HEAD OR RAPID DECELERATION

891.32.text:
OF THE HEAD THAT RESULTS IN A BRIEF PERIOD
OF BEING KNOCKED OUT; OR NOT REMEMBERING,

897.30.text: WHICH WE CALL AMNESIA; OR BEING CONFUSED.

900.42.text:
SO IT'S ONE OF THOSE THREE THINGS THAT WILL
GET YOU A DIAGNOSIS OF A CONCUSSION.

904.42.text: THERE'S NO LAB TEST OR X-RAY.

907.18.text: IT'S BASED SOLELY ON THOSE SYMPTOMS.

910.10.text:
THERE'S PROBLEMS WITH THAT, OBVIOUSLY, BECAUSE
IF PEOPLE CAN'T REMEMBER WHAT HAPPENED, THAT

915.92.text:
MAKES IT HARD FOR DOCTORS TO DIAGNOSE WHETHER
YOU'VE HAD A CONCUSSION OR NOT.

920.60.text: BUT UNFORTUNATELY IN 2013 THAT'S WHAT WE HAVE.

925.11.text:
DUSTIN, FROM RALEIGH, NORTH CAROLINA, ASKS,
"IF A CAT SCAN DOESN'T RULE OUT A CONCUSSION,

931.53.text:
IN A SMALL PERCENTAGE OF PEOPLE THAT HAVE
CONCUSSION, THERE CAN BE BLEEDING IN THE BRAIN.

935.74.text:
IT'S NOT POSSIBLE TO TELL WHO'S GOT BLEEDING
IN THE BRAIN JUST BY THOSE SYMPTOMS OF LOSS

943.30.text:
THAT'S WHY IT'S IMPORTANT TO GET A CAT SCAN,
AND IT'S HARD TO KNOW WHO NEEDS A CAT SCAN

947.43.text:
WITHOUT ACTUALLY GOING TO A DOCTOR IN AN EMERGENCY
ROOM OR TALKING TO YOUR DOCTOR ON THE PHONE

954.86.text:
EVERY CONCUSSION HAS THE POTENTIAL FOR THIS
LIFE-THREATENING BLEEDING IN THE BRAIN THAT

959.79.text:
CAN ONLY BE DETECTED WITH A CT SCAN OR MRI.
AND THAT'S MEDICINE.

966.09.text: NOT SURE IF IT'S MYTH OR MEDICINE?

969.23.text: WE WILL GET TO WORK AND GET YOU A SECOND OPINION.

976.24.text:
MONICA, THANK YOU FOR STAYING WITH US ACROSS
THE BREAK.

978.57.text: MONICA IS A 24-YEAR-OLD -- GOT THE AGE RIGHT?

980.87.text:
-- GRADUATE STUDENT, AND YOU HAD A FEW HARD
HITS TO YOUR HEAD PLAYING SOCCER, OF ALL GAMES.

986.59.text:
I MEAN, IT'S SUPPOSED TO BE THIS NON-CONTACT
SPORT.

989.37.text:
I HAVE A FEELING I'M MISINTERPRETING THE WAY
SOCCER'S PLAYED.

993.57.text: YEAH, LOTS OF CONTACT IN THE WOMEN'S GAME.

996.11.text:
YOU'RE NOW AN ASSISTANT COLLEGE COACH, AND
YOU'RE NOT ACTIVELY PLAYING, RIGHT?

999.43.text:
AND YOU QUIT PLAYING BECAUSE YOU DIDN'T WANT
ANY MORE HITS TO THE SQUASH.

1007.98.text:
I MEAN, IF SHE KEPT GETTING HIT, WAS SHE GOING
TO PERHAPS LOSE SOME FUNCTIONAL BRAIN POWER?

1012.47.text:
I THINK IT WAS A GOOD DECISION, GIVEN HER
SYMPTOMS.

1014.47.text:
WHAT ARE THE SHORT-TERM VERSUS THE LONG-TERM
COMPLICATIONS OF CONCUSSIONS?

1018.51.text:
SO, SHORT TERM, YOU CAN HAVE HEADACHES, YOU
CAN HAVE NAUSEA, DYSFUNCTION, A LITTLE CONFUSION

1026.63.text:
AND COGNITIVE DYSFUNCTION, AND I'LL TURN IT
TO YOU FOR THE LONG TERM, BECAUSE I CAN TALK

1033.59.text:
WELL, I THINK LONG TERM YOU WORRY ABOUT, DOES
AN ATHLETE'S REPETITIVE CONCUSSIONS AND POST-CONCUSSION

1038.39.text:
SYMPTOMS LEAD TO A POTENTIALLY SEASON-ENDING
PROBLEM, A POTENTIALLY CAREER-ENDING PROBLEM,

1046.06.text:
WHERE THEY HAVE TO RETIRE, AS SHE ULTIMATELY
DID, OR CAN IT AFFECT THEM LATER IN LIFE?

1050.17.text:
CAN THEY END UP WITH CHRONIC HEADACHES OR
IN A FEW CASES EVEN CHRONIC BRAIN INJURY TYPE

1056.05.text: SYNDROME, MORE SO FROM PROFESSIONAL ATHLETES.

1059.96.text:
BUT THEY REALLY, THEY GET PAID TO TAKE THESE
HITS.

1062.96.text:
WELL, THEY DO, AND THEY HAVE AN UNPRECEDENTED
AMOUNT OF EXPOSURE THROUGH THE YEARS TO THOUSANDS

1066.94.text:
I'M REMINDED OF THE PUNCH-DRUNK SYNDROME,
WHERE BOXERS TYPICALLY WOULD SIT IN A GYM

1075.38.text:
BELIEVED TO OCCUR IN ABOUT 20% OF RETIRED
PROFESSIONAL BOXERS.

1079.28.text: AND THEY GET POUNDED ALL THE TIME.

1080.28.text:
IN FACT, WHEN THEY GO DOWN ON THE CANVAS,
THAT IS A CONCUSSION, ISN'T IT?

1088.39.text:
SO THE LONG TERM, IF YOU KEEP GETTING HIT
LIKE THIS, IS LONG-TERM BRAIN INJURY?

1094.49.text:
SO IS THERE A WAY TO SO CONSTRUCT, LET'S SAY,
SOCCER, SO THAT YOU DON'T GET THIS?

1098.60.text: IS IT ALWAYS GOING TO BE A PART OF THIS GAME?

1102.11.text:
I MEAN, THE ONLY WAY TO DO THAT IS TO NOT
HAVE CONTACT, WHICH WE DON'T THINK IS GOING

1104.36.text:
TO HAPPEN IN SOCCER OR MANY OF THE OTHER SPORTS
THAT OCCUR.

1107.82.text:
I THINK THE IMPORTANT THING IS TO RECOGNIZE
THAT -- TO DO EARLY AND QUICK EVALUATION.

1113.01.text:
IF A PLAYER TAKES A HIT, IF THEY FALL, TO
NOT ALLOW THE PLAYER TO MAKE THE DECISION

1118.32.text: WHETHER OR NOT TO ENTER THE GAME.

1120.08.text:
TAKE IT AWAY AND MAKE IT OBJECTIVE AND REALLY
ALLOW THEM TO REST.

1125.31.text:
IF A DOCTOR SAYS, "DO YOU WANT TO GO IN,"
THE ATHLETE IS ALMOST ALWAYS GOING TO SAY

1128.35.text: THAT CAN'T BE THE SINGLE DETERMINING FACTOR.

1130.83.text: NOW, YOU STILL HAVE HEADACHES, DON'T YOU?

1135.68.text:
I MEAN, I HAVE MILD HEADACHES MAYBE ONCE OR
TWICE A WEEK AND SEVERE HEADACHES MAYBE ONCE

1141.07.text: A MONTH, ONCE EVERY TWO MONTHS OR SO.

1144.58.text: WHAT HAVE YOU TRIED FOR THAT?

1146.58.text:
THROUGHOUT THIS WHOLE PROCESS, I'VE GONE THROUGH
A NUMBER OF DIFFERENT TREATMENTS.

1148.63.text:
I'VE TRIED A COUPLE DIFFERENT FORMS OF PHYSICAL
THERAPY.

1153.23.text: I'VE TRIED CHANGING MY DIET, CHANGING MY EXERCISE.

1160.48.text: SO, NO SUCCESS WITH ANY OF THIS?

1163.69.text:
UM, SOME OF THEM HAD A LITTLE BIT OF HELP
KIND OF LIKE RELIEVING SYMPTOMS, BUT I GUESS

1167.58.text:
NO LONG-TERM SUCCESS, NOTHING THAT ELIMINATED
THEM COMPLETELY.

1171.69.text:
AGAIN, WE TALKED ABOUT THIS AND I MENTIONED
IT, YOU TALKED ABOUT MIGRAINE.

1175.25.text:
IS THIS MORE LIKE MIGRAINE, OR DO YOU THINK
WE CAN BLAME THIS, CAN YOU BLAME THIS ON A

1182.61.text:
WELL, I WOULD CALL IT POST-TRAUMATIC MIGRAINE,
WHICH IS A VARIANT.

1184.81.text: IT'S A VARIANT OF POST-CONCUSSION SYNDROME?

1190.53.text:
OKAY, SO IT IS RELATED, YOU THINK, TO THE
CONCUSSIONS?

1193.53.text:
IT SOUNDS LIKE IT IN TERMS OF WHEN IT BEGAN,
AND IT HASN'T STOPPED COMPLETELY SINCE THAT

1197.61.text: DO THESE THINGS EVER JUST GO AWAY BY THEMSELVES?

1201.61.text:
I THINK THE BRAIN HEALS, AND WHATEVER ONGOING
PROCESS IS OCCURRING, WHETHER IT'S CHRONIC

1205.80.text:
INFLAMMATION OR SOMETHING ELSE, WILL SETTLE
DOWN, BUT SHE'S STRUGGLED WITH IT, I CAN SEE.

1213.66.text:
PART OF THE ISSUE -- WE'VE GOT TO LET HER
BRAIN REST.

1216.53.text:
SHE WENT THROUGH COLLEGE AND WAS STUDYING
ALL THE TIME AND NOW SHE'S IN GRADUATE SCHOOL,

1220.05.text:
AND SHE'S CONTINUING TO UTILIZE HER BRAIN
--

1223.13.text:
BUT WAIT, LET ME SEE IF I UNDERSTAND WHAT
YOU ARE SAYING, THAT USING YOUR BRAIN TO STUDY

1227.78.text: WILL HURT THE HEALING PROCESS FROM A CONCUSSION?

1232.22.text:
THAT'S LIKE IF YOU BREAK YOUR LEG AND YOU
KEEP RUNNING ON IT.

1235.97.text: BUT SHE'S NOT HITTING IT INTO A WALL.

1238.97.text:
SHE DOESN'T HAVE TO HIT IT, IT'S THE COGNITIVE
FUNCTION.

1240.97.text: IS THAT -- DO YOU AGREE WITH THAT?

1244.97.text:
THAT'S A DIFFICULT TRADE-OFF IN LIFE, AND
THAT'S A DIFFICULT TRADE-OFF FOR STUDENT ATHLETES.

1247.63.text:
IT'S DIFFICULT FOR PEOPLE WHO MAKE A PROFESSION
PLAYING ATHLETICS.

1253.27.text:
FOR ANY WALK OF LIFE, IT'S HARD TO PUT YOUR
LIFE ON HOLD.

1256.45.text:
SO MANAGING THAT STIMULATION, FOR INSTANCE
FOR KIDS, WE DON'T WANT THEM TO PLAY VIDEO

1261.41.text: GAMES AND HAVE ALL THAT STIMULATION.

1263.99.text:
BUT AFTER A CERTAIN PERIOD OF TIME, IF YOU
KEEP THEM OUT OF SCHOOL TOO LONG, IT'S DIMINISHING

1276.33.text: WHERE DO YOU THINK YOU ARE ON THAT?

1277.33.text:
ARE YOU READY NOT TO GO TO SCHOOL FOR A WHILE
AND SIT IN A DARK ROOM AND LET YOUR BRAIN

1281.33.text:
I MEAN, AND THAT'S ONE OF THE REASONS I STOPPED
? I DECIDED TO STOP PLAYING BECAUSE I WANTED

1283.35.text: TO MAKE SURE THAT I COULD FINISH MY DEGREE.

1286.04.text:
BUT SHE'S ACTUALLY SAYING FINISHING YOUR STUDIES
MIGHT AT LEAST IN PART BE CONTRIBUTING TO

1293.35.text:
WELL, I STARE AT A COMPUTER SCREEN ALL DAY
LONG EVERY DAY FOR MY WORK, SO I WOULD IMAGINE

1299.88.text:
WHICH BRINGS US TO THE REASON THAT YOU'RE
REALLY HERE, AMONG MANY, BUT YOU'RE HERE FOR

1305.33.text: WE HAVE GREAT EXPERTS FOR YOU.

1307.35.text:
THIS IS YOUR OPPORTUNITY TO ASK YOUR QUESTIONS
FOR A SECOND OPINION.

1312.08.text:
YEAH, I'VE STARTED TRACKING MY HEADACHES,
SO I WRITE DOWN EVERY TIME I GET THEM AND

1316.66.text:
AND IS THIS JUST SOMETHING I SHOULD LIVE WITH
AND DEAL WITH?

1320.00.text:
OR WHAT WOULD YOU SUGGEST AS FAR AS SEEKING
TREATMENT OR SEEING SOMEBODY?

1326.89.text:
I THINK YOU NEED TO SEE A HEADACHE SPECIALIST
AND NOT JUST A NEUROLOGIST OR A NEUROSURGEON,

1330.86.text:
BUT SOMEONE WHO REALLY SPECIALIZES IN HEADACHES
AND PARTICULARLY MIGRAINE OR POST-TRAUMATIC

1335.28.text:
MIGRAINE, BECAUSE I THINK THERE ARE SOME TREATMENTS
OUT THERE THAT IT DOESN'T SOUND LIKE YOU MAY

1341.25.text:
THERE IS SOME PREVENTATIVE THERAPY THAT MAY
BE BENEFICIAL TO YOU.

1345.69.text:
SOUNDS LIKE SHE'S TRIED A LOT, AND I AGREE,
YOU'VE MADE A GREAT EFFORT AT TRYING TO OVERCOME

1350.02.text:
THIS, AND I WOULD AGREE THAT A HEADACHE SPECIALIST,
ORDINARILY A NEUROLOGIST OR HEADACHE CLINIC,

1356.26.text:
HAS THE MOST EXPERTISE AND CAN MAKE THE MOST
PROGRESS.

1359.08.text:
A LOT OF IT IS PART OF LIFESTYLE -- THAT INCLUDES
DIET, EXERCISE, SLEEP PATTERNS, HOW YOU MANAGE

1364.28.text: YOUR WORK AND YOUR SCHOOL AND STUDY RESPONSIBILITIES.

1367.78.text:
BUT PROBABLY THAT'S THE STAGE YOU'RE AT NOW,
THAT YOU NEED THAT EXPERTISE.

1377.14.text:
I JUST WONDER, IS THIS, AM I, SHOULD I EXPECT
TO DEAL WITH HEADACHES FOREVER?

1382.94.text: OR IS IT SOMETHING THAT COULD BE --

1386.05.text:
I WOULD SAY, NO, I DON'T THINK YOU SHOULD
EXPECT TO LIVE WITH PAIN FOR THE REST OF YOUR

1391.99.text:
I THINK THAT'S SOMETHING THAT CAN BE AGGRESSIVELY
--

1394.41.text: I'LL GIVE YOU THE LAST WORD.

1397.41.text: I AGREE, I THINK THERE'S OPTIMISM.

1398.41.text:
YOU'RE NO LONGER GETTING THAT STIMULUS OF
HITTING YOUR HEAD ALL OF THE TIME, BUT IT'S

1400.91.text:
A COMMITMENT TO GETTING BETTER, WHETHER IT'S
MEDICATION OR ALL THE LIFESTYLE THINGS.

1406.68.text:
I WANT TO THANK BOTH OF YOU FOR BEING HERE,
AND, MONICA, THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR SHARING

1410.10.text:
YOUR STORY, AND I HOPE WE GAVE YOU A SECOND
OPINION THAT WAS AT LEAST PARTIALLY HELPFUL.

1414.51.text:
AND NOW FOR THE LAST WORD ON CONCUSSIONS,
HERE IS THIS WEEK'S "SECOND OPINION 5."

1422.64.text:
ELIZABETH MURRAY, AND I'M HERE TO TELL YOU
THE FIVE SIGNS OF WHEN TO GO TO THE EMERGENCY

1428.02.text:
THE FIRST SIGN IS LARGE BRUISING AT THE SITE
OF INJURY.

1430.48.text:
BUMPS AND BRUISES ARE COMMON, BUT A LARGE
AMOUNT OF SWELLING OR BRUISING, OFTEN CALLED

1434.58.text:
A GOOSE EGG, ON THE SIDES OR THE BACK OF THE
SKULL CAN BE CONCERNING.

1438.69.text:
HOW THE INJURY HAPPENED IS ALSO A FACTOR TO
TAKE INTO CONSIDERATION.

1441.66.text:
A FALL FROM STANDING IS ALMOST NEVER GOING
TO HURT YOU, BUT A FALL ON A ROCK IS A DIFFERENT

1447.80.text:
INJURIES FROM HARD OR SHARP OBJECTS WILL OFTEN
CAUSE THAT BRUISING AND SWELLING WE JUST DISCUSSED.

1452.46.text: THE THIRD SIGN IS UNCONTROLLED VOMITING.

1454.42.text:
NO ONE WANTS TO FEEL NAUSEOUS OR THROW UP,
BUT ONE OF TWO EPISODES OF VOMITING CAN BE

1459.41.text:
IT'S THE PERSON WITH UNCONTROLLED VOMITING
OR PROFOUND NAUSEA THAT WARRANTS FURTHER EVALUATION.

1463.37.text:
IF YOU'RE EXPERIENCING ALTERED MENTAL STATE
OR AMNESIA, THIS IS ANOTHER SIGN TO GET YOU

1468.04.text: OR YOUR LOVED ONE TO THE EMERGENCY ROOM.

1470.06.text:
CONFUSION IS COMMON FOR A FEW MINUTES AFTER
A HEAD INJURY, BUT IF A PERSON IS REPEATING

1474.45.text:
THE SAME QUESTION OVER AND OVER AGAIN OR REALLY
SEEMS OUT OF IT, HAVE THEM EVALUATED.

1478.01.text:
AND THE LAST SIGN IS LOSS OF CONSCIOUSNESS
OR SEIZURES, AND THIS IS A TRUE MEDICAL EMERGENCY.

1484.09.text:
IF A PERSON IS KNOCKED OUT FOR MORE THAN FIVE
SECONDS OR APPEARS TO BE HAVING SEIZURES,

1487.90.text:
THEN YOU NEED TO STAY WITH THEM AND HAVE SOMEONE
CALL 911.

1491.26.text:
REMEMBER, YOU KNOW YOUR COMFORT LEVEL BEST,
AND YOU KNOW YOUR CHILD BEST.

1494.65.text:
IF SOMETHING SEEMS WRONG TO YOU OR YOU ARE
UNCOMFORTABLE, REACH OUT TO YOUR PEDIATRICIAN

1498.83.text: OR COME SEE US IN THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT.

1511.04.text: THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR WATCHING "SECOND OPINION."

1513.36.text:
WE HOPE THAT YOU CONTINUE THIS CONVERSATION
ON OUR WEBSITE, WHERE YOU CAN COMMENT ON THE

1517.39.text:
SHOW, SEND US YOUR SHOW IDEAS, OR EVEN SHARE
YOUR HEALTH STORY WITH US, AND MAYBE WE'LL

1522.79.text: EVEN INVITE YOU TO BE ON THE SHOW WITH US.

1531.63.text:
PETER SALGO, AND I'LL SEE YOU NEXT TIME FOR
ANOTHER "SECOND OPINION."

Child: THERE ONCE WAS A TIME WHEN WE WERE
TRULY FREE -- FREE OF WORRY, FREE OF FEAR,
